summary:
I am a wildlife bioligist with a special interest in the diversity and distribution of (Philippine) birds, mammals, amphibians and reptiles and in the impact of anthropogenic activities on their populations. Apart from studying wildlife and publishing the results I also try to apply my knowledge to the actual conservation of species and habitats in northern Luzon, Philippines. I am co-founder and director of the Philippine registered non-profit Mabuwaya Foundation, an environmental Civil Society Organisation implementing community-based conservation activities. Mabuwaya started as a small Philippine crocodile conservation project but now has grown into one of the largest environmental CSOs of northern Philippines with ten staff and an annual budget of approx. 200,000 USD. 

In addition to research and conservation work in the Philippines, I remain interested in wildlife studies and conservation in the Netherlands and in sub-saharan Africa where I conducted fieldwork for my BSc and MSc Biology (Schiermonnikoog, Cameroon, Mozambique) and where I started my professional career (Waza-Logone Project in Cameroon). 

I am a part-time lecturer at the Institute of Environmental Sciences (CML) and at the department of Cultural Anthropology at Leiden University. I teach the course "Transdisciplinary Skills"in the Master Governance of Sustainability, and the course "Area Study Philippines" in the Minor Sustainable Development. The Area Study Philippines (previously known as the "Water Course Philippines") includes one month of fieldwork in the Philippines in collaboration with Isabela State University. Students of both universities work together on an interdisplinary research topic related to sustainable development and environmental conservation, such as water management, the impact and response to Typhoons and reforestation.  

I am a wildlife photographer and writer of more than 100 scientific and popular articles on Philippine wildlife including three coffee table books.

I am available for consultancy work.
